text: Well, it's important because a guy named Gerald Ferris developed a scale of political skill. And he and a bunch of his colleagues over the years did a lot of empirical research that demonstrates that political skill is associated with a lot of positive outcomes, salary, getting promoted, being happy in your career, being happy in your job, being less stressed. So the reason why you should pay attention to this is because it leads to a lot of good things.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Lenny asks Jeffrey why it's important for people to learn about power despite it making them uncomfortable. Jeffrey explains that political skill has been scientifically proven to correlate with career success and wellbeing. He references research by Gerald Ferris showing that developing political skills leads to concrete benefits including higher salaries, more promotions, greater job satisfaction, and reduced stress levels.
text_ko: 중요한 이유가 있어요. 제럴드 페리스(Gerald Ferris)라는 분이 '정치적 기술'(political skill)이라는 척도를 개발했고, 그와 동료들이 수년간 실증 연구를 통해 이 정치적 기술이 연봉, 승진, 경력·직무 만족도, 스트레스 감소 등 여러 긍정적 결과와 연관돼 있다는 걸 보여줬어요. 그래서 관심을 가져야 해요—결국 많은 좋은 일로 이어지니까요.
text_zh: 这个很重要，因为有个叫Gerald Ferris的人开发了一套政治技能量表(political skill scale)。他和同事们这些年做了大量实证研究(empirical research)，证明政治技能跟很多好结果都有关系——涨工资、升职、职业发展顺心、工作开心、压力也小。所以你应该关注这个，因为它能给你带来很多好处。
text_es: Bueno, es importante porque un tipo llamado Gerald Ferris desarrolló una escala de habilidades políticas. Y él junto con varios colegas suyos hicieron durante años un montón de investigación empírica que demuestra que las habilidades políticas están relacionadas con muchos resultados positivos: mejor salario, conseguir ascensos, estar contento en tu carrera profesional, estar a gusto en tu trabajo, tener menos estrés. Así que la razón por la que deberías prestarle atención a esto es porque te lleva a muchas cosas buenas.

text: I think we've confused the tool for how it has been used. I see people with hammers hitting other people on the head. That does not mean that a hammer is not a useful tool. You can take a screwdriver and stab it into somebody's belly. I have a very dear friend who we'll probably talk about later in the podcast. Laura Esserman is a breast cancer surgeon, and I tell people, Laura has a knife. She uses it to cure cancer.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Lenny mentions that power-building techniques feel uncomfortable because they're not how people want to live their lives. Jeffrey responds by explaining that people have developed negative associations with power because they've seen it misused. He uses analogies comparing power to tools like hammers, screwdrivers, and surgical knives - arguing that the tool itself isn't inherently bad, but rather depends on how it's used by the person wielding it.
text_ko: 저는 우리가 도구 자체와 그 도구가 실제로 어떻게 쓰였는지를 혼동하고 있는 것 같아요. 망치를 들고 다른 사람 머리를 때리는 사람들을 보곤 해요. 그렇다고 해서 망치가 쓸모없는 도구라는 건 아니에요. 드라이버로 누군가의 배를 찌를 수도 있죠. 제가 아주 친한 친구가 한 분 있는데, 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 나중에 아마 얘기할 거예요. 로라 에서먼(Laura Esserman)은 유방암 외과의사(breast cancer surgeon)이에요. 저는 사람들에게 '로라에겐 칼이 있다'고 말하곤 해요. 그녀는 그 칼로 암을 치료해요.
text_zh: 我觉得我们把工具本身和它的使用方式给搞混了。就好比我看到有人拿锤子砸别人脑袋，但这不代表锤子本身不是个有用的工具啊。你也可以拿螺丝刀捅别人肚子，对吧？我有个特别好的朋友，我们待会儿在播客里可能会聊到她。Laura Esserman是个乳腺癌外科医生，我跟别人说，Laura手里有把刀，但她是用这把刀来治癌症的。
text_es: Creo que hemos confundido la herramienta con el uso que se le ha dado. Veo gente que agarra un martillo y le pega a otros en la cabeza. Eso no significa que un martillo no sea una herramienta útil. Puedes tomar un destornillador y clavárselo a alguien en el estómago. Tengo una amiga muy querida de la que probablemente hablaremos más tarde en el podcast. Laura Esserman es cirujana de cáncer de mama, y yo le digo a la gente: Laura tiene un bisturí. Lo usa para curar el cáncer.

text: The class is extremely popular. I have a long waiting list. It's kind of mythical. And because of the principle of social influence, we are influenced by what other people do. We're influenced in our choices of restaurants, we're influenced in our choices of music. I'm not sure I like Taylor Swift, but I certainly want to go see Taylor Swift because everybody else is.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Lenny asks why Jeffrey's class isn't for everyone and why being less judgmental is important. Jeffrey explains that his Stanford course has become extremely popular with long waiting lists, creating a mythical reputation. He discusses the principle of social influence - how people are influenced by what others do in their choices of restaurants, music, and even classes, using Taylor Swift as an example of how popularity itself drives more interest.
text_ko: 이 수업은 엄청 인기 있어요. 대기자 명단도 길고, 왠지 전설 같은 느낌이에요. 그리고 사회적 영향력(principle of social influence) 때문에 우리는 다른 사람들 하는 대로 영향을 받아요. 식당을 어디로 갈지나 어떤 음악을 들을지도 다들 하는 걸 보고 결정하죠. 저는 테일러 스위프트를 정말 좋아하는지는 잘 모르겠지만, 다들 가니까 저도 꼭 보러 가고 싶어요.
text_zh: 这个课程特别火，我这儿排队等着上课的人一大堆。这课程都成传说了。其实这就是社会影响力的原理，我们会被别人的行为影响。选餐厅的时候我们会看别人去哪儿，听音乐也会跟风。我其实不确定自己是不是真的喜欢泰勒·斯威夫特，但我肯定想去看她的演唱会，因为大家都去看。
text_es: La clase es súper popular. Tengo una lista de espera larguísima. Se ha vuelto como algo mítico. Y por el principio de influencia social, nos dejamos influir por lo que hace la demás gente. Nos influye a la hora de elegir restaurantes, nos influye en la música que escuchamos. No sé si realmente me gusta Taylor Swift, pero desde luego quiero ir a verla porque todo el mundo va.

text: If I decide that Lenny is whatever set of bad adjectives you want to use, dumb, incompetent, immoral, whatever, my ability to build a positive relationship with you, and you remain on my critical path, becomes almost zero unless you're a better actor or I'm a better actor than I think most people are. So therefore, you should suspend judgment in the sense that if somebody is on your critical path, the only judgment you should make is they're on my critical path.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Jeffrey explains why being judgmental hinders professional effectiveness. He describes how jobs require interdependence and getting things done through other people. When someone is on your 'critical path' (essential to accomplishing your work goals), making negative judgments about them severely damages your ability to build the positive working relationship you need, regardless of personal feelings about that person.
text_ko: 제가 레니(Lenny)를 멍청하고, 무능하고, 비도덕적이라고 결론내린다면—어떤 부정적 형용사든 상관없어요—당신이 제 크리티컬 패스(critical path)에 계속 남아 있는 한 당신과 긍정적인 관계를 쌓을 수 있는 가능성은 거의 없어져요. 당신이 평소 사람들보다 훨씬 더 잘 행동하거나 제가 평소 사람들보다 훨씬 더 잘해야 가능한데, 그걸 기대하기는 어렵죠. 그래서 판단을 보류하는 게 좋아요. 누군가가 당신의 크리티컬 패스에 있다면, 내리는 유일한 판단은 '그 사람이 내 크리티컬 패스에 있구나' 정도면 충분해요.
text_zh: 如果我认定Lenny就是各种不好的词汇，比如笨、没能力、品德有问题什么的，那我跟你建立良好关系的可能性基本为零，除非你我都是超级会演戏的人，但我觉得大部分人都做不到这样。所以你应该暂时不要下判断，如果某个人在你的关键路径(critical path)上，你唯一需要判断的就是——他在我的关键路径上，仅此而已。
text_es: Si decido que Lenny es todo lo malo que se te ocurra—tonto, incompetente, inmoral, lo que sea—mi capacidad de construir una relación positiva contigo, cuando tú sigues siendo clave para mi proyecto, se vuelve prácticamente cero, a menos que tú o yo seamos mejores actores de lo que creo que es la mayoría de la gente. Por eso, debes suspender el juicio en el sentido de que si alguien está en tu ruta crítica (critical path), lo único que debes pensar es "esta persona está en mi ruta crítica" y ya.

text: And Derek Kan was a little bit older when he went through the MBA program. And in 2012, his Doing Power project was to get appointed to be Mitt Romney's, it was Mitt Romney was running for president, to be head of economic policy for the Romney campaign. Believe it or not, he was offered the job. Believe it or not, he turned it down for reasons which we could go into if you want, but aren't that interesting. He wound up relatively soon thereafter as number three in the transportation department, working for Elaine Chao.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Lenny asks about examples from Jeffrey's homework assignments called 'Doing Power' projects where students practice power-building skills. Jeffrey shares the extreme example of Derek Kan, an MBA student who set a goal to become head of economic policy for Mitt Romney's presidential campaign. Despite being offered the position (which he declined), this experience led to high-level government positions, ultimately running the $6 trillion US budget just six years after business school.
text_ko: 데릭 칸은 MBA 프로그램(MBA program)을 다닐 때는 나이가 좀 더 있었어요. 2012년에 그의 Doing Power 프로젝트(Doing Power project)는 밋 롬니가 대선에 출마했을 때 롬니 캠프의 경제정책 책임자(head of economic policy)로 임명되는 것이 목표였어요. 믿기 어렵겠지만 실제로 그 제안을 받았고, 더 놀랍게도 그 제안을 거절했어요. 이유는 원하시면 얘기해드릴 수 있지만 별로 흥미롭진 않아요. 그 뒤 얼마 지나지 않아 그는 교통부(Department of Transportation)에서 3인자 자리에 올라 엘레인 초 밑에서 일하게 되었어요.
text_zh: Derek Kan读MBA的时候年纪稍微大一点。2012年的时候，他的实践项目(Doing Power project)是想去给竞选总统的Mitt Romney当经济政策负责人。你可能不信，人家真的给了他这个机会。你可能更不信的是，他居然拒绝了——原因嘛，要是你想听我可以说说，不过其实也没那么有意思。之后没多久，他就去了交通部，在Elaine Chao手下当三把手。
text_es: Y Derek Kan era un poco mayor cuando hizo el MBA. Y en 2012, su proyecto de Doing Power era conseguir que lo nombraran como jefe de política económica para la campaña de Mitt Romney, que en ese momento se postulaba para presidente. Aunque no lo creas, le ofrecieron el puesto. Aunque no lo creas, lo rechazó por razones que podríamos platicar si quieres, pero que no son tan interesantes. Poco después terminó como número tres en el departamento de transporte, trabajando bajo Elaine Chao.

text: There are by definition fewer positions at the top than at the bottom. The world, we might not like this, and I know people, the late Tony Hsieh, the Zappos tried to do holacracy or whatever, but the world is essentially hierarchical. The animal kingdom is hierarchical. It is better to be at the top than at the bottom for a number of reasons. Okay. If that is true, if there are fewer positions at the top and then at the bottom, then your job to advance your career is to figure out how to get promoted.
speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
context: Lenny asks Jeffrey to explain the power of building a personal brand, which makes people uncomfortable. Jeffrey begins by explaining the fundamental reality of organizational hierarchies - there are fewer positions at the top than at the bottom, making competition inevitable. He acknowledges that while some have tried alternatives like holacracy, hierarchical structures remain dominant in both human organizations and nature, making career advancement necessarily competitive.
text_ko: 기본적으로 위쪽 자리가 아래쪽보다 적어요. 이걸 좋아하지 않을 수도 있고, 이미 세상을 떠난 토니 셰이 같은 사람들은 Zappos에서 홀라크러시(holacracy) 같은 걸 시도하기도 했죠. 하지만 세상은 본질적으로 위계적(hierarchical)이에요. 동물의 세계도 마찬가지고요. 여러 가지 이유로 위쪽에 있는 게 아래에 있는 것보다 나아요. 그게 사실이라면, 위쪽 자리가 적다는 걸 전제로 당신의 커리어를 진전시키려면 어떻게 승진할지를 알아내는 것이 당신의 일이에요.
text_zh: 很简单的道理，越往上职位越少，越往下职位越多。这个世界就是这样，咱们可能不爱听，我知道有些人，比如已故的托尼·谢（Tony Hsieh），Zappos那家公司试过什么全员制（holacracy）之类的，但这个世界本质上就是有等级的。动物世界也是这样，弱肉强食。在上面肯定比在下面强，这个道理大家都懂。好，既然上面的位子少，下面的位子多，那你想往上爬，就得琢磨怎么升职。
text_es: Por definición hay menos puestos arriba que abajo. Al mundo, puede que no nos guste esto, y conozco gente, como el difunto Tony Hsieh, el de Zappos que intentó hacer holacracia o como se llame, but el mundo es esencialmente jerárquico. El reino animal es jerárquico. Es mejor estar arriba que abajo por varias razones. Bueno. Si eso es cierto, si hay menos puestos arriba que abajo, entonces tu trabajo para hacer crecer tu carrera es descifrar cómo conseguir un ascenso.
